Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Homelessne.Homelessness_with_annotation: Floodwaters briefly isolated 15 houses during the storm.
Six homes were destroyed and 120 others were damaged in Salter Path.
In Emerald Isle, 25 people required rescue.
Hurricane-force wind gusts caused minor damage to about 500 homes.
Eight duplexes were undermined by the erosion, potentially rendering them uninhabitable.
A total of 388 homes were damaged across Onslow County, five of which were condemned.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Injury.Injury_with_annotation: One indirect fatality was linked to the hurricane when a car hydroplaned on a rain-slicked road in Franklin County.
Only one power outage occurred, affecting 130 residents in Stewiacke.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Ophelia was a long-lived tropical cyclone in September 2005 that moved along an erratic path off the East Coast of the United States for much of its existence. The fifteenth named storm and the eighth hurricane of the record-breaking 2005 Atlantic hurricane season, Ophelia originated from a complex set of systems across the Atlantic in early September.

Total_Death_Per_Country.Death_with_annotation: Rough seas led to one fatality in Florida and left another person missing in South Carolina while rain-slicked roads contributed to a fatal accident in North Carolina.
Atlantic Canada saw negligible effects as Ophelia's remnants traversed the region; one person died after falling from his roof while preparing for the storm.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Rough seas led to one fatality in Florida.
Rough seas led to one fatality in Florida and left another person missing in South Carolina.

Total_Summary_Insured_Damage.Total_Insured_Damage_Assessment_with_ann: An initial insured damage estimate of $800 million, yielding an approximate $1.6 billion in total damage, was given soon after the storm. However, later assessments by the American Insurance Services Group gave an insured loss estimate of $35 million, yielding a total cost of $70 million.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Displaceme.Displacement_with_annotation: A public shelter was opened in Daytona Beach, Volusia County; only 13 people used the shelter and were relocated to a Red Cross facility.
Statewide, approximately 2,000 people sought refuge across 45 shelters.
At least 95 people used public shelters in Wilmington.
Evacuations were ordered for a 20-block area of Washington that had flooded during Hurricane Fran in 1996.
Mandatory evacuation orders were issued for the approximately 800 tourists on Ocracoke Island on September 11.
The Red Cross opened three shelters across both counties; only 25 people used them.
Statewide, approximately 2,000 people sought refuge across 45 shelters.
Only one power outage occurred, affecting 130 residents in Stewiacke.

Location: East Coast of the United States

Location_with_Annotation.Bahamas: An area of low pressure consolidated near the Bahamas and was classified as Tropical Depression Sixteen on September 6.
Location_with_Annotation.East Coast of the United States: Hurricane Ophelia was a long-lived tropical cyclone in September 2005 that moved along an erratic path off the East Coast of the United States for much of its existence.
Location_with_Annotation.Atlantic Canada: Remaining on a steady east-northeast to northeast path for the next week, Ophelia traversed Atlantic Canada and the northern Atlantic Ocean before dissipating on September 23 over the Norwegian Sea.
Location_with_Annotation.Florida: Tropical storm-force wind gusts and heavy rain caused minor damage in Florida.
Location_with_Annotation.Georgia: Effects from Ophelia in Georgia were limited to the immediate coastline, with these areas largely receiving 3 in (76 mm) of rain at most.
Location_with_Annotation.South Carolina: Tropical storm-force wind gusts and heavy rain caused minor damage in ... South Carolina.
Location_with_Annotation.North Carolina: The greatest impacts were felt in North Carolina, where more than 240,000 people lost power and more than 1,500 homes were damaged.
Location_with_Annotation.Virginia: Virginia Governor Mark Warner declared a state of emergency and activated the National Guard.
Location_with_Annotation.Maryland: The Maryland Emergency Management Agency held daily briefings on the storm, though effects in the state were expected to be minimal.
Location_with_Annotation.Delaware: Rip currents were reported in coastal Delaware on September 16 to 17.
Location_with_Annotation.New Jersey: The combination of onshore flow and a full moon led to minor coastal flooding in Cape May and Monmouth counties in New Jersey.
Location_with_Annotation.New York: Several streets in Suffolk County, New York, became impassible from swiftly moving water.
Location_with_Annotation.Connecticut: Flash floods occurred in Fairfield and New London counties in Connecticut.
Location_with_Annotation.Massachusetts: Ophelia brought locally heavy rain and gusty winds to southeastern Massachusetts as it brushed the state late on September 16.
Location_with_Annotation.Maine: Maine ... received minimal rainfall with state accumulations peaking at 1.5 in (38 mm).
Location_with_Annotation.New Hampshire: New Hampshire ... received minimal rainfall with state accumulations peaking at 1.84 in (47 mm).
Location_with_Annotation.Vermont: Vermont ... received minimal rainfall with state accumulations peaking at 0.6 in (15 mm).
Location_with_Annotation.Nova Scotia: Meteorologist Ted McIldoon at the CHC described Ophelia as a 'typical storm for [Atlantic Canada].' Heavy rain affected much of Nova Scotia while the strongest winds remained offshore.
Location_with_Annotation.Newfoundland: In Newfoundland, over 2.0 in (50 mm) of rain fell over parts of the eastern region of the province.
Location_with_Annotation.New Brunswick: Farther west, portions of New Brunswick received up to 1 in (25 mm) of rain.

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Economic_Damage_Assessment_with_an: An initial insured damage estimate of $800 million, yielding an approximate $1.6 billion in total damage, was given soon after the storm. However, later assessments by the American Insurance Services Group gave an insured loss estimate of $35 million, yielding a total cost of $70 million.

Meteorologist Ted McIldoon at the CHC described Ophelia as a 'typical storm for [Atlantic Canada].' Heavy rain affected much of Nova Scotia while the strongest winds remained offshore.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Economic_D.Economic_Damage_Assessment_with_annotati: An initial insured damage estimate of $800 million, yielding an approximate $1.6 billion in total damage, was given soon after the storm. However, later assessments by the American Insurance Services Group gave an insured loss estimate of $35 million, yielding a total cost of $70 million.
Heavy rainfall across Brunswick County caused widespread flooding. At least 200 homes were damaged on Bald Head Island and floodwaters briefly isolated 15 houses during the storm.
Damage across Carteret County was primarily concentrated in coastal communities and barrier islands. Numerous docks and piers were damaged or destroyed.
Damage across the county reached $4.9 million, with barrier islands suffering the brunt of damage.
Damage across Pender County reached $1.5 million, and was primarily concentrated in Surf City and on Topsail Island.
A total of 388 homes were damaged across Onslow County, five of which were condemned.
The Marine Corps Base Camp Lejeune suffered $1.2 million in damage, with the majority coming from the 300 ft (91 m) Riseley Pier.

Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Wind: The greatest impacts were felt in North Carolina, where more than 240,000 people lost power and more than 1,500 homes were damaged.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Rainfall: Some coastal locales saw heavy rain, notably more than 15 in (380 mm) in the Outer Banks of North Carolina.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Flood: Heavy rainfall across Brunswick County caused widespread flooding. At least 200 homes were damaged on Bald Head Island and floodwaters briefly isolated 15 houses during the storm.

In Emerald Isle, 25 people required rescue.
Damage across the county reached $4.9 million, with barrier islands suffering the brunt of damage. A total of 636 structures sustained varying degrees of damage with wind being the primary cause.
Damage across Pender County reached $1.5 million, and was primarily concentrated in Surf City and on Topsail Island. Hurricane-force wind gusts caused minor damage to about 500 homes.
A total of 388 homes were damaged across Onslow County, five of which were condemned.
The Marine Corps Base Camp Lejeune suffered $1.2 million in damage, with the majority coming from the 300 ft (91 m) Riseley Pier.
The greatest impacts were felt in North Carolina, where more than 240,000 people lost power and more than 1,500 homes were damaged.
